cluster_relations.rel_desc: The tale 'Hansel and Gretel' tells the story of the sibling characters Hansel and Gretel.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: two siblings who are abandoned in the woods

remarks: Characters entity is the canonical sibling duo mentioned as 'two siblings.'

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The cannibalistic witch owns the house made of sweets.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: at the time the siblings find it

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Hansel and Gretel fairytale features Hansel as one of its child protagonists.
remarks: Captures story–character inclusion even though this may also be modeled as a node property elsewhere.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Hansel and Gretel fairytale features Gretel as one of its child protagonists.
The Hansel and Gretel fairytale features the witch as its main antagonist.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The narrative work includes the referenced character or group of characters as part of its story.
args.justification: All these relations link the specific tale 'Hansel and Gretel' to one or more of its characters, with the semantics that the story features or includes those characters narratively. Differences in role (protagonist, antagonist, siblings) are captured via qualifiers and do not change the predicate meaning.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject has ownership or possession of the object.
args.justification: This relation describes property ownership: the witch owns the house made of sweets. This is distinct from narrative inclusion and should use a standard possession predicate.
These edges all express that a narrative work includes certain characters in its cast, a coherent family of relations about character participation in a story.
This edge represents an ownership/possession link between an agent (the witch) and an asset/location (the house). It belongs to a distinct class of ownership relations.
A story's set of characters can be treated as part of its compositional content; these relations describe how the narrative is composed in terms of characters it includes.
The relation encodes an ownership/possession link, which falls naturally under a broad POSSESSION group distinct from composition or causality.
